Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Becoming Boundary Spanners: Investigating, Enhancing, and Assessing the Experiences of Early Career Engineers

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This engineering education research project supported by the CAREER program will enable an early career researcher to investigate how engineering degree programs can develop students to act as boundary spanners who can communicate, collaborate, and coordinate across organizational, disciplinary, geographic, demographic, stakeholder, and other boundaries. Such skills are increasing necessary for engineers to function effectively in a globalized workforce. The project will investigate the nature of boundary-spanning competencies both in degree programs and the workforce, as well as explore how degree programs can enhance these competencies. The study uses a sequential mixed-methods design and will develop a measure to assess key dimensions of boundary spanning competence in engineering practice.

The broader significance and importance of this project arises from the project's attempt to integrate a range of 21st Century skills into one measurable competency, then develop ways to assess and teach this competency. Such attempts can have systemic impact by informing degree programs about ways to reduce time to degree while maintaining the ability to graduate engineers with skills needed by today's workforce. This project overlaps with NSF's strategic goals of transforming the frontiers through preparation of an engineering workforce with new capabilities and expertise. Additionally NSF's goal of innovating for society is enabled by supporting the development of innovative learning systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Background
Gaps persist between what engineering students learn in the classroom versus the realities they face in the workplace, leaving graduates underprepared for their careers and employers dissatisfied with new employees. At the same time, the nature of engineering work continues to change due to intensified globalization dynamics, frequent corporate restructuring, rapid technological change, shifting disciplinary boundaries, and other trends. More empirical studies of engineering practice are needed to illuminate the day-to-day realities of engineering work and improve engineering education.

Purpose
The purpose of this project was to investigate the job expectations and day-to-day working experiences of early career engineers in large manufacturing companies. We adopted boundary spanning as the primary conceptual framework for our research. In brief, boundary spanning occurs when an individual coordinates, collaborates, and/or communicates across various types of boundaries, such as organizational, stakeholder, demographic, time and space, expertise, knowledge, etc. This project more specifically aimed to identify boundary spanning roles, competencies, and strategies important for engineers and other technical professionals.

Approach
This project had four main phases. In the first, we performed a qualitative systematic literature review to identify and analyze 72 scholarly papers on boundary spanning and engineering. Second, we collected interview and reflection data from 29 early career engineers, then used a thematic analysis approach to identify boundary spanning activities, boundary types, and related themes. Third, we continued prior efforts to develop and validate situational judgment test (SJT) questions that can be used to evaluate and improve the ability of engineers to span national/cultural and other boundaries. Fourth, we initiated a study of boundary spanning experiences among engineers transitioning into management roles.

Results
This research has led to development and dissemination of new frameworks and typologies for the phenomenon of boundary spanning, while demonstrating the utility of boundary spanning as a useful concept for investigating and characterizing key aspects of engineering practice. We identified three main kinds of strategies that are important in boundary spanning situations, namely: connect (proactively seek out connections and relations), relate (build and maintain relationships), and communicate (enable bidirectional communication to get work tasks completed). Data and findings from this project also highlight many understudied aspects of engineering work, including challenges associated with the school-to-work transition and onboarding processes, and the emotional and psychological dimensions of early career practice. Another key observation centers on the sociotechnical nature of practice, with engineers frequently engaging in social interactions as well as developing and utilizing technical expertise. To provide more holistic and compelling portrayals of the day-to-day experiences of early career engineers, we produced and published multiple narratives of engineering practice. These accounts especially help illuminate patterns of early career progression, with evidence of significant increases in informal and formal leadership responsibilities during the first years of a typical engineer's career.

Conclusions
This project underscores the importance of boundary spanning as an important "meta-attribute" or "meta-competency" for current and future engineers. This in turn suggests a continuing and urgent need to provide students and professionals with meaningful simulations of practice, such as through the use of problem- and project-based learning (PBL) to help them develop both professional and technical skills. Our research also confirms the value of situational and scenario-based approaches to instruction and assessment. Finally, this project provided one undergraduate and seven graduate students with training and experience in qualitative social science research methods, and one undergraduate and one graduate student with software development experience.
